opinions.title: Fixing the City Charter
opinions.author: Aleksey Gurtovoy
opinions.blurb: What if it was much easier for us to change the Constitution than to change the laws that have to follow it?

opinions.title: Measure C won't turn Iowa City into California
opinions.author: Martha Hampel
opinions.blurb: Some Iowa City residents expressed concern that passing Public Measure C could “turn Iowa City into California” by bringing too many ballot issues to voters.

opinions.title: Educate yourself on Measure C
opinions.author: Gary Gussin
opinions.blurb: Measure C, which will appear on the back of our ballots this November, is intended to make the city charter requirements for an initiative or referendum conform to state code.

opinions.title: Remember to turn the ballot over
opinions.author: Jeff Cox
opinions.blurb: Many people have voted early, but if you have not voted yet, it is important to turn the ballot over and vote on the often overlooked choices on the back of the ballot.

opinions.title: Ballot measure deserves your vote
opinions.author: Caroline Dieterle and Carol DeProsse
opinions.blurb: Despite the overall liberal nature of Iowa City, the city council has been historically conservative, primarily controlled by development, banking and related interests; its policies over the years to date have reflected this.

opinions.title: Measure C deserves your support
opinions.author: Karen Kubby
opinions.blurb: Iowa City is one of the few places in Iowa where people can petition its representative government to either retract something they don’t like that was passed, or to initiate a local law.

opinions.title: Measure C is an antidote to special interests
opinions.author: Aleksey Gurtovoy
opinions.blurb: A recent letter argued that Measure C “will make it easier for special interests to influence local government”. It’s an interesting claim, considering that  “special interests” are about the only ones who can take advantage of the Iowa City’s current initiative and referendum process.

opinions.title: November Ballot to Include Petition Signature Requirement
opinions.author: Maria Houser Conzemius
opinions.blurb: In November 2016 Iowa City voters will have an opportunity to vote on how many signatures the city should require to bring a valid initiative/referendum issue to the city council's attention for council passage or placement on a city election ballot.

opinions.title: Fear, Uncertainty and Doubt
opinions.author: Aleksey Gurtovoy
opinions.blurb: Old guard to Iowa City voters: “Don’t change the status quo, or all hell will break lose.”

opinions.title: The Sky Has Already Fallen, Mr. Balmer
opinions.author: Aleksey Gurtovoy
opinions.blurb: Hey, Mr. Balmer, your doomsday scenario has been in place for the last 40 years.

opinions.title: When is 5.33% a round number?
opinions.author: Aleksey Gurtovoy and Martha Hampel
opinions.blurb: When you need a rationale for an otherwise baseless decision, anything resembling some sort of logic will do.

opinions.title: Turn the Ballot Over!
opinions.author: Jeff Cox
opinions.blurb: If you vote in Iowa City you will find on your presidential ballot, hidden away at the bottom of the back page, an amendment to the City Charter. The amendment looks complicated but it is in fact a simple one.
